data.title: Write an Example Game

milestone.title: Future
milestone.description: New systems and modules requiring a significant amount of long-term effort.

data.body:
As stated [here](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/issues/1), the next step in documenting Duality should be to create an example game project everyone can download from the package manager and play and mess with immediately. Quoting the original idea:

After finishing the cloning issue, a new sample project would be great:
- Dual Stick space shooter with newtonian physics, minimalistic graphics
- Main Menu Scene
- Input via Mouse / Keyboard and Gamepad
- Several Level Scenes
- Highscore Scene
- Simple ParticleSystem Component
- Audio
- Should be able to handle any screen resolution and adapt Rendering to it.

A project like this would have the secondary benefit of a larger evaluation phase for previous changes and the state of Duality as a whole. Additionally, the following could improve the situation for newbies:
- Set up the project within the Duality master branch so it will always be up-to-date.
- Allow Package Management to deliver source code. Will need to auto-remap .csproj project references to local files.
- Create a package containing the sample project.
- Allow DualityEditor to detect whether it has first started from a new installation and ask the user whether he wants to download the sample project package.

data.title: Package Compatibility Checks

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
[_Note on Milestone:_ This is a **prerequisite for v2.0**, not a real part of it]
- Right now, it is quite easy to break a Duality environment by doing an update that isn't backwards-compatible while still having other packages referring to the old version.
- There should be compatibility checks that, by default, only allow updating when something like this is very unlikely.
  - The rules for direct compatibility between two dependent packages are already defined and quite easy. The problem arises from arbitrarily complex package combinations and dependency relations.
- The API for safety checks is already in place, as is the editor representation. Need to implement the actual algorithm.

**Immediate ToDo:**
- Compatibility checks for updating a single package.
- Compatibility checks for updating a group of packages.
- Automatically determining the highest possible version configuration of a set of packages that still satisfies a certain compatibility level.
- Maybe write some unit tests for package management?

data.title: Creating prefabs from child game objects is broken
data.body:
Hello

Not sure when this bug crept in but it's easy to repro.
1. Create a game object in a new scene
2. Add a child game object to that game object (neither of these have to have any components)
3. Create a prefab from the child game object.
4. The first issue happens now. The prefab is created but the scene will have an instance of it in the root.
5. Next, play the scene, then stop. The child prefab will have disappeared from the parent.

Tested this on the most recent vanilla Duality.

Thanks

data.title: Write More Unit Tests

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
Duality already incorporates automated testing into its development and deployment cycle. However, these tests barely cover even half of Duality and while full coverage may not be necessary, a little bit more than now can't be too bad.

Testing Guidelines:
- **Minimize dependencies** of a single Test. The more things you rely on, the easier the test will break unconditionally due to core updates, and the more maintenance it requires.
- **Prefer custom Types** for testing generalized behavior. When testing Component logic, write a custom Test Component rather than using SpriteRenderer, etc.
- **Focus on fixed spec areas** when writing new tests. Don't test stuff that is in-development or about to change, as it will only increase maintenance for now. Tests should be focused on making sure that things remain in a working condition. Don't write a test, if that "working condition" isn't clearly defined yet.
- [Read this](http://www.adamslair.net/blog/?p=1463)

Things to think about how to test:
- Audio: Is there any way to "render to memory" with OpenAL, so Audio output can be tested? Especially tests for streaming would be great.
- Editor: Is there any way to test the user interface? Prior to this: Is there a good way to test editor functionality / logic without the user interface?

data.title: Upgrade to Framework Version 4.5
data.body:
Adam, 

I wasn't sure how much collaboration you were hoping for on this project so I chose a small issue and cranked it out. I don't think you need VS 2012 in order to run the CS projects since this upgrade is an "in place" upgrade, but there may be a few missing files between the minor release versions. 

However, if you are looking for contributors here are the changes required to move the project from framework version 4.0 to framework version 4.5.

There was no problems when performing this upgrade since .NET framework
4.0 to .NET framework 4.5 is an in place upgrade. This means all
existing files are only upgraded not replaced (this is a minor release
not a major release).

As a matter of fact, there is no directory for the 4.5 framework there
is only a directory for the 4.0 version (this directory being 4.0.309
[not sure where it's located sorry])

I have done many similar upgrades at my current job. From framework 4.0
to 4.5 and between C++ toolsets (toolset v10.0 to toolset v11.0)

I ran across a pretty obscure bug in the editor yesterday where the game pauses if you press alt while focus is set on a detached game view window (The update loop stops rather than a time scale freeze). This is causing problems when using any game inputs mapped to the alt key

Set up a scene with a rigidbody, attached sprite renderer and a camera.
Set the active view to game view and undock the window from the editor
Press play and when the body starts falling press alt
The body then stops falling until another input is detected

data.title: Upgrade to .Net 4.5

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
Consider upgrading from .Net 4.0 to .Net 4.5 in order to gain access to the improved API and features of .Net 4.5.

Pro:
- Generic collections now implement IReadOnlyXY<T> interfaces that can replace the often used IEnumerable<T> accessors, where the only reason to use them was read-only access.
- System.IO.Compression will be able to replace Ionic.Zip dependency. The less external dependencies, the better.

Neutral:
- Might need to upgrade to VS2012 as well.
- Async File I/O and async stuff due to VS2012 would be a good opportunity to get to know all those async features and apply them where Duality previously used yield constructs.
- High DPI improvements for WinForms in .Net 4.5.2 could be worth a look, in case worrying about High DPI ever becomes an actual issue.
- Will need to look into the new Type and TypeInfo distinction for Reflection. Probably need to re-implement or upgrade a lot of Reflection methods in Duality, if Type needs to be replaced with TypeInfo. Worst case, though.

Con:
- Increased end user requirements. **This is probably a knock-out. Just wait for a while, then reconsider later.**

data.title: Worry about High DPI Displays
data.body:
Dualitor, based on WinForms and with a lot of custom Controls, is not DPI aware and will fall back to DPI virtualization on Windows 8. This allows users to work with it, but its UI may look a little blurry and doesn't take advantage of high DPI rendering.
- Investigate the possibilities of [WinForms High DPI support](http://blogs.telerik.com/winformsteam/posts/14-02-11/winforms-scaling-at-large-dpi-settings-is-it-even-possible-)
- Fix all custom Controls that use fixed pixel sizes for stuff to scale with DPI settings
  - PropertyGrid
  - Docking
  - Other?
- Investigate whether DPI virtualization is actually fine with regard to # of users affected and degree of blurriness / usability caveats. Don't do, if it turns out to be not really worth it in the end.

data.title: Rewrite the Cloning System
data.body:
As stated in issue #103, there is currently no easy way to customize cloning behavior other than taking over completely, either by overriding OnCopyTo (Components, Resources), or by implementing ICloneExplicit (other classes).
- The apparent problem is the default behavior of explicitly unwrapping only ICollection types whenever cloning Duality classes.
- The underlying problem to solve is how the CloneProvider determines which references of an object are actually references, and which refer to objects that are to be considered dependent parts of the current object.
- Introduce a new attribute that identifies a class or a field as dependent / non-autonomous object.
  - Whenever that attribute is active, the affected objects are cloned deeply instead of assigning their reference only. This is not overridable by explicit unwrapping behavior.
  - If it's applied to a class, all occurrences of it will be affected.
  - If it's applied to a field, the stored object will be affected. 
  - Special case: If that stored object is an ICollection, all of it's elements will be affected.
    - This does NOT mean all of the collections fields will be affected, just the objects that are to be considered elements of the collection, i.e. objects with collection.Contains(obj) being equal to true.
    - The same holds true for collections of collections. And what about dictionaries and other key-value collections? That sounds messy.
    - Also, calling Contains is not a good idea, as it might be a "non-const" operation for some collections.
    - Better idea: Pass the effect of that field on as long as there is an unbroken chain of deeply-cloned objects from the current object to the one that was directly affected by the field attribute.

data.title: Allow to remove Components and Children from Prefabs

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
- Right now, it's impossible to ever remove Components or child GameObjects from a Prefab without having to create a new one and/or updating all of its instances.
- From a users perspective, this is unusable, and also a ridiculous asymmetry.
- From a technical side, the reason is that Prefabs allow their instances to carry additional Components and child GameObjects, which in turn means that they're never allowed to remove things, only to add and update.

Come up with a way on how to handle this and allow users to update their Prefabs accordingly.

data.title: AppData StartScene should be StartScene Path
data.body:
Since appData is a configuration file, all property types should be basic values.

AppData is probably going to have StartScene set automatically in a build step to an existing scene, however to set this value, an instance of this scene must exist, is it really necessary to load a scene just to set this value? or would it be better that appData simply stores the path to it  (in the end the serialized information is pretty much the same) but the way to deal with it is simpler

``` C#
         var appData = FetchAppData(pathToAppData);

         appData.Version = version;
         appData.StartScenePath = @"relative/Path/to/Start.Scene.res"
```

data.title: Game objects not serializing properly from inside dictionaries
data.body:
Sample project to repro here - https://www.dropbox.com/s/zx78tcbqsb983mp/ReproGameObjectReferencesInDictionaries.zip

Drag ComponentWithDictionary from Project View into Scene View to create an instance, and observe in the Object Inspector that clicking the eye icon beside the GameObject property does not flash the game object called Child in Scene View. This is because the reference to Child is not being maintained.

This seems to be happening because the serialization code is recognizing the child game object and the reference to that object as two different game objects, so it's not serializing the reference as an ObjectRef type, but rather as a separate game object.

This needs to be fixed ASAP. Duality should build "out of the box". Any idea what the source of this could be? Some broken config file maybe?

data.title: Improve Maintnance of Optional Plugins
data.body:
## Problem
- Right now, optional plugins like Steering and DynamicLighting are prone to errors, since they are almost never tested. 
- The issue will likely become larger and larger, since more optional plugins may be added to the repository over time.
## Solution
- Modify Nightlybuild to always build all plugins, but copy only the standard ones into the package. If a build error occurs, stop and report.
- Add some basic Unit Tests for plugins and add them to the Unit Testing queue, either by including them in the default NUnit project, or by creating more NUnit projects that will be invoked by NightlyBuilder.
- To keep compile and loading times down, think about splitting the monolithic Duality VS solution into multiple solutions. Maybe one containing everything, one only for the standard version without optional plugins?
  - Make sure to always favor adding projects over referencing prebuilt Assemblies, within the Duality repository itself.
